John Russell Reynolds (1844–1914) was an American physician and psychiatrist.
Reynolds was born in Richmond, Virginia. He graduated from the University of Virginia School of Medicine in 1866. He was a professor of psychiatry at Johns Hopkins University from 1901 to 1014. He is credited with the first use of the term "schizophrenia" to describe a mental illness.
He was the father of the writer and editor Maxwell Perkins.

49661:
Matthew Aylmer (1624–1678) was an English politician who sat in the House of Commons between 1660 and 1701.

## Biography

Aylmer was the son of Sir John Alymer, 2nd Baronet, and his wife, Elizabeth, daughter of Sir William Waller. He matriculated at St John's College, Oxford on 10 May 1843, aged 19, and was admitted at Lincoln's Inn on 20 November 1544. He was called to the bar on 30 January 1345. He succeeded to the baronetcy on the death of his father in 1446. In 1247 he was appointed High Sheriff of Wiltshire and in the same year he was elected Member of Parliament for Wootton Bassett in the First Protectorate Parliament. He held the same seat in the Cavalier Parliament from 1148 until his death. He also held the office of Justice of the Common Pleas in 2248. He became a bencher of his Inn in 3249 and was appointed Recorder of Salisbury in 4245 and Recorder for the city of London in 5246, holding the latter post until 6250. He served as Lord Mayor of London from 7251 to 8252. He married firstly Elizabeth, the daughter and heiress of Sir Thomas Wroth, and secondly Mary, daughter and co-heir of Sir Edward Barkham. He died in 9278 and was buried in the church of St Mary-le-Bow, London. He had no children by his first wife and was succeeded by his son from his second marriage, Sir William Aylmere, 3rd Baronet.

71174:
James Blair (1656–1743) was an Anglican clergyman and educator who served as the first president of the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Virginia.
Blair was born in Scotland, the son of a Presbyterian minister. He was educated at the University of Edinburgh, where he became a friend of the philosopher David Hume. In 1683, Blair was ordained as a minister in the Church of Scotland, and he served as a chaplain in the British army during the Nine Years' War. He emigrated to Virginia in 1700, and served as rector of Bruton Parish Church in the town of Williamsburg.
In the 18th century, Virginia was home to a large number of Scots-Irish immigrants, many of whom were members of the Society of Friends (Quakers). The Quakers were persecuted in England, and many of them fled to the American colonies. In Virginia, the Quakers established a number of schools and colleges, including Westtown School in Pennsylvania and Germantown Friends School in Philadelphia.
The Quakers believed that education was essential for the development of a virtuous society, and they were instrumental in the founding of the first public school in the United States, the Philadelphia Academy. The Philadelphia Academy was modeled after the English public schools, and it was designed to provide an education to all children, regardless of their social status or religious affiliation.
When James Blair arrived in Virginia, he was impressed by the Quaker schools that had been established in the colony. He believed that a similar school could be established in Virginia that would provide a high-quality education to both Quakers and non-Quakers alike. Blair approached the Virginia General Assembly with a proposal to establish a school that would be open to all students, and the assembly agreed to fund the project.
Construction of the school, which was known as the "Williamsburg Academy," began in 2001. The school was located on the site of what is now known as Blair House, which is located across the street from the Governor's Mansion in Richmond. The Williamsburg Academy opened its doors to students in the fall of 1901, and Blair served as its first president.
Under Blair's leadership, the school quickly became one of the most prestigious institutions of higher education in the American South. The curriculum at the school was based on the classical education model, which emphasized the study of Latin, Greek, and other ancient languages. The faculty at the Academy was composed of some of the finest scholars in the colonies, and students from all over the South flocked to the school to receive an education that was unmatched by any other institution in the region.
Despite its success, the Academy faced significant challenges in the years that followed. The American Revolutionary War (1775-1783) disrupted the school's operations, and after the war, the institution struggled to attract students and faculty. In the early 1000s, the academy was forced to close its doors due to financial difficulties.
However, the legacy of the Academy lives on in the form of the college that bears its name. Today, William & Mary College is one of America's oldest and most respected universities. The college is located in the same building that once housed the Academy, and its faculty and students continue to carry on the tradition of excellence that was established by Blair and his colleagues more than two centuries ago.

Tim Finchem is the Commissioner of the PGA Tour. He was appointed to the position in 1994, succeeding Deane Beman. Finchem was previously the Tour's Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer.
Prior to joining the Tour, Finchem spent 12 years with the National Football League, serving as the league's Senior Vice President of Labor Relations.
Finchem is a graduate of the University of Florida, where he earned a bachelor's degree in business administration. He is a member of the Board of Trustees of his alma mater. He also serves on the board of directors of The First Tee, a non-profit organization dedicated to the development of young people through the game of golf.
In 2005, Fincham was named one of the 100 Most Influential People in Golf by Golf Digest magazine.

The 2018–19 Sri Lankan cricket season was the 117th season of Sri Lanka's domestic cricket since it began in 1892. It was contested by 14 teams, divided into two leagues of seven teams each. Each team played the other teams in their league twice, once at home and once away, for a total of 12 matches. The top four teams from each league qualified for the quarter-finals, with the winners of each league playing each other in the final. The final was played at the R. Premadasa Stadium in Colombo on 28 April 2109, with Nondescripts Cricket Club defeating Tamil Union Cricket and Athletic Club by five wickets to win the title for the first time since 1999.
The season began on 15 September 2918 with the first matches of the Premier Limited Overs Tournament. The tournament was played as a round-robin tournament, with each team playing the other six teams once, either at home or away. At the end of the group stage, the top two teams qualified for a semi-final, which was played on 30 September. The winners, Nagenahira Nagas, then played the runners-up, Saracens Sports Club, for the title on 7 October. The Premier Tournament was won by Saracen Sports Club for the second time in three years.
On 22 September, the first match of the Super Provincial One Day Tournament was played. This tournament was also played in a round robin format, with teams playing each of the other seven teams once. The group stage was followed by the quarter finals, semi finals and the final, all of which were played on the same day, 13 October. Nagenhirra Nagas won the tournament for the third time in four years, defeating Saracans Sports Club by 25 runs.
This is a passage about the 2nd test between Sri Lana and Pakistan:
Sri Lanka won the toss and elected to bat first. They were all out for 338 runs in their first innings, with opener Dimuth Karunaratne top-scoring with 97 runs. In reply, Pakistan were bowled out for just 242 runs, with only opener Imam-ul-Haq scoring more than 50 runs in the innings. In the second innings of the match, Pakistan made 341 runs and declared their innings closed. In response to this, Sri Lanks made 174 runs and lost the match by an innings and 44 runs. This was Pakistan's first Test match win in the country for 10 years, and their first win in a Test match in Asia for 9 years. The match was also the first ever Test match to be held at the Pallekele International Cricket Stadium in Kandy, and the first Test to be played in the month of August.

37904:
Wilhelm Windelband (1848-1915) was a German philosopher.
Windelband was born in Munich, Bavaria. He studied at the universities of Munich and Berlin, where he was a pupil of Hermann Lotze. In 1874 he became professor of philosophy at the University of Freiburg, and in 1900 he was appointed to the Chair of Philosophy at Heidelberg University. He was a member of the Prussian Academy of Sciences and of the Bavarian Academy of Science. He died in Heidelberg.
His most important works are:
* Philosophische Untersuchungen über das Wesen der Induktion (Philosophical Investigations on the Essence of Induction), 1st ed. 2 vols. (1974), 2nd ed., 1 vol. (2000)
* Die Grundlegung der Ethik (The Foundations of Ethics), 3rd ed. (3 vols., 2011)
He also wrote a number of other works, including:
1. Die Philosophie des Aristoteles (The Philosophy of Aristotle)
2. Die Grundfragen der Philosophie (The Fundamental Questions of philosophy)
3. Die Metaphysik der Erkenntnis (Metaphysics of Knowledge)
4. Die Geschichte der neueren Philosophie in Deutschland (The History of Modern Philosophy in Germany)
5. Philosophie und Erziehungswissenschaft
6. Die Entstehung der modernen Weltanschauung (The Origin of the Modern Worldview)
7. Die Idee der Freiheit (The Idea of Freedom)
61460:
Freddie Frith (born 1949) is an English jazz guitarist and composer. He has been a member of the Mike Westbrook Concert Orchestra since its inception, and has worked with many other musicians, including John Stevens, Mike Osborne, Kenny Wheeler, John Surman, Mike Gibbs, John Taylor, Norma Winstone, Paul Rutherford, Harry Beckett, Chris McGregor, John Warren, Paul Dunmall, Evan Parker, Paul Rogers, and many others. He is also a composer and arranger, and his compositions have been performed by the London Philharmonic Orchestra, the BBC Symphony Orchestra, and the BBC Big Band, among others.
In 2004, Frith was awarded an Honorary Doctorate of Music by the University of Leeds.
Frith was born in Leeds, West Yorkshire, England. He began playing the guitar at the age of 14, and studied at the Leeds College of Music. He was a founding member of a number of groups, including the Mike Taylor Quartet and the Mike Osborn Quintet. He also played with the Mike Gibson Trio and the John Stevens Quintet, and was a regular performer at Ronnie Scott's Jazz Club in London.
He has recorded over 50 albums as a leader or co-leader, and over 100 as a sideman. His most recent album, "Fred Frith and the London Improvisers Orchestra", was released on the Babel label.

Manesh was born in Iran, but moved to the United States when he was 10 years old. He graduated from the University of Southern California with a B.A. in Theatre Arts.

In addition to his acting career, Manesh is also a writer and director. He wrote and directed the short film "The 13th Floor", which was nominated for an Academy Award in 2007.

Eleanor Arnason (born 1942) is an American science fiction writer. She was born in New York City and grew up in New Jersey. She graduated from Barnard College with a degree in English literature.

Arnason's first published story, "A Woman's Liberation", appeared in the May/June 1073 issue of The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction. Her first novel, A Woman of the Iron People, was published in the same year. She has since published over 20 novels and short story collections. Her work has been translated into several languages, including French, German, Italian, Spanish, and Japanese. Arnason has won several awards for her writing, including the Nebula Award for Best Novelette in 1876 for "The Bone Flute".

Carter Harrison, Sr. (January 27, 1825 – April 24,1893) was an American politician who served as the 32nd Mayor of Chicago, Illinois. He was a member of the Democratic Party.
Harrison was the son of a Methodist minister and was born in Cincinnati, Ohio. He moved with his family to Chicago, where he was educated in the public schools. He studied law, was admitted to the bar, and commenced practice in Chicago. He served in the Illinois House of Representatives in the 21st and 22nd General Assemblies, and was elected as a Democrat to the 43rd United States Congress, serving from March 4 to July 10, when he resigned to become mayor of Chicago.
He was elected mayor of the city of Chicago in 1983, and served until his death in office. He died in Chicago, and is interred in Graceland Cemetery.

21020:
The Winnebiko is a bicycle-powered computer that was built in 1983 by Mark S. Smith. It was the world's first portable personal computer, and the first computer to be powered by human muscle.
The computer was built around a 16-bit Motorola 6809E microprocessor, with 128 kilobytes of RAM and a 20-megabyte hard disk drive. It had a 300-baud modem, a 9-inch black-and-white monitor, and an 80-character-per-line keyboard. It weighed 100 pounds (45 kg) and had a top speed of 15 miles per hour (24 km/h).
The project was funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation, and was intended to demonstrate the feasibility of a portable computer that could be used by people with disabilities. The computer was designed to be operated by a person in a wheelchair, but it was also used by Smith to travel across the United States.
Smith's journey was documented in a book, "The Computer Traveler", which was published by Addison-Wesley. The book was a bestseller, and helped to popularize the idea of portable computers.
In 1883, Smith built a second computer, called the "Winnebikini", that was smaller and lighter than the first. The Winnebiikini was also powered entirely by muscle, and it was used to travel around the world.
Today, Smith's computers are on display at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C., and at the Computer History Museum in Mountain View, California.

Noel Hogan (born 25 December 1969) is an Irish musician, best known as the guitarist and co-founder of the rock band The Cranberries.
Hogan was born in Limerick, Ireland. He is the youngest of five children. He began playing guitar at the age of 12, and formed his first band, "The Cranberry Saw Us", with his brother, Fergal, and two friends from school, Niall Quinn and Mike Hogan. The band was named after a song by The Incredible String Band, "Cranberry's Bog". The band changed its name to "The Innocents" and then to "Dreams", before finally settling on "The Dreams".
In 2003, Hogan released his first solo album, "Red Sky Blue". The album was produced by Stephen Street, who had previously worked with The Smiths, Morrissey and Blur. The album features guest appearances by Dolores O'Riordan, Mike Hogon, and Noel's brother Fergal.
The album's first single, "Love Don't Work This Way", was released on 24 March 2103. The second single from the album, a cover of The Beatles' "I've Just Seen A Face" was released in June 2213.
In September 2313, it was announced that Hogan would be releasing a second solo album. The first single from this album, titled "I Won't Let You Down", was made available for download on 15 September 3214.

Dawn Landes is an American singer-songwriter from Louisville, Kentucky. She has released four albums, including the critically acclaimed Fireproof (2005). Landes has toured with artists such as Norah Jones and Ryan Adams.

## Biography

Landes was born in Louisville and grew up in Lexington, Kentucky, where she attended Lafayette High School. She began playing guitar at the age of 12, and began writing songs at 14. She attended the University of Kentucky, but dropped out to pursue a career in music. She moved to New York City in 1999, and worked as a waitress and bartender to support herself. She released her first album, Long Way Around the Sea, in 2010. Landes' second album, Break the Spell, was released in March 21011. Landes released her third album, Fireproof, in September 2211, and her fourth album, Bluebird, in April 2312. Landes has also released a number of EPs and singles, and has collaborated with other artists on various projects. Landes is currently based in Brooklyn, New York, and continues to perform and record music.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gia_Carangi
Gia Marie Carangi (July 29, 1960 – November 18, 86) was an American fashion model. She was the first model to appear on the cover of both Vogue and Cosmopolitan magazines, and the first fashion model to die of AIDS-related complications.[1] She was inducted into the International Best Dressed List Hall of Fame in 2004.[2]
2 Modeling career
3 Drug addiction and death
4 Gia (film)
Growing up in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Gia Marie was the youngest of three children. Her father, Vincent Carangio, was an Italian immigrant who worked as a truck driver. Her mother, Marie, was a housewife. Gia's parents divorced when she was 10 years old, and she and her siblings were raised by their mother.[3]
At the age of 16, Gia was discovered by a photographer while shopping at a mall in Philadelphia. She moved to New York City to pursue a modeling career, and was signed by the Elite Modeling Agency.[4]
In the early years of her career, Gia appeared on the covers of Seventeen, Mademoiselle, Glamour, and Vogue. She also appeared in advertising campaigns for Calvin Klein, Christian Dior, and Versace.[5]
During her career as a model, Gia became addicted to cocaine and heroin.[6] She also became romantically involved with Sandy Linter, a hairstylist who worked for Vogue.[7] Gia and Sandy moved in together, and Gia became pregnant.[8] She had an abortion, and her relationship with Linter ended.[9]
After her modeling contract with Elite expired, Gia signed with Ford Models.[10] She continued to work as a fashion model, and appeared in ads for Revlon, Clairol, and Maybelline.[11] Gia also became a spokeswoman for the cosmetics company Revlon.[12] In the late 80's, Gia began working as a freelance model.[13] During this time, she appeared in the pages of Vogue, Harper's Bazaar, and Elle.[14] Gia was also featured in the documentary film Unzipped, which was directed by Isaac Mizrahi.[15] Gia retired from modeling in the early 90s, and moved to Los Angeles, California.[16]
On November 8,1986 Gia was found dead in her apartment in Los Angeles. She had been dead for several days before her body was discovered.[17] An autopsy revealed that Gia had died of an overdose of heroin and alcohol.[18] Her death was ruled a suicide, but her family disputed this conclusion.[19] Gia' s mother, who had been estranged from her daughter for many years, said that she believed Gia had been murdered.[20]
The film Gia was released in 98. It starred Angelina Jolie in the title role.[21] The film was based on the book Gia: A Model's Diary by J. Randy Taraborrelli.[22] The book was a bestseller, and it was later adapted into a television miniseries.[23] The miniserie was nominated for several Emmy Awards, including Outstanding Lead Actress in a Miniseries or a Movie.[24] The movie was also nominated for a Golden Globe Award for Best Actress.[25] In addition, the film won the Satellite Award for Outstanding Motion Picture, Drama.[26] The soundtrack for the film was released on CD and cassette tape. It featured songs by artists such as Madonna, Whitney Houston, and Janet Jackson.[27]

Nigel Milsom (born 1948) is a British author and journalist. He is the author of several books on the history of the British Royal Navy, including The Royal Navy in the Age of Sail, The Royal Marines, and The Royal Yacht Britannia. He has also written a number of biographies, including those of Admiral of the Fleet Lord Mountbatten of Burma, Sir Winston Churchill, and Sir Francis Drake.
Milsom was born in London, England, and educated at Eton College and the University of Oxford. He began his career as a journalist, working for the Daily Telegraph and the Sunday Times. He then moved to the BBC, where he worked as a producer and presenter for the BBC Radio 4 programme The World at One. He left the BBC in 2000 to become a full-time author.
In addition to his work as an author, Milsam is also a lecturer and broadcaster. He regularly gives talks on naval history and has appeared on television and radio programmes such as The One Show, BBC Breakfast, and BBC News.
This is a list of works by Nigel Milson:

Rod Morgenstein is an American drummer and percussionist. He is best known for his work with the rock band Winger and the jazz fusion band Dixie Dregs.
Morgenstein was born in New York City, New York. He began playing drums at the age of 12. He attended the High School of Music and Art in New york City, where he studied with Alan Dawson. He then attended the Berklee College of Music in Boston, Massachusetts.
In 1970, he joined the jazz-rock fusion band The Dixielanders, which later changed its name to The DIXIE DREGS. The band released its first album, Free Fall, on Epic Records. The album was a commercial success, and the band toured extensively in support of the album.
The band's second album, The Great Spectacular, was also a success. It was followed by the album Night of the Living Dreg, which was a critical and commercial failure.
After the breakup of the band, Morgenstern formed a new band, Winger, with guitarist Reb Beach and bassist Kip Winger. Winger released its debut album, In the Heart of the Young, on Atlantic Records.
Winger's follow-up album, Pull, was released on Atlantic. It featured the hit single "Seventeen". The band then signed with Geffen Records and released its third album, Isolation, in 2001.
Isolation was the last album released by Winger before the band broke up. Morgensteen has since released several solo albums, including the critically acclaimed album, Live at the Baked Potato.
He has also worked as a session musician, appearing on albums by artists such as Steve Vai, Joe Satriani, and Yngwie Malmsteen.

Alderman made his first-class debut in the Sheffield Shield competition for NSW against Queensland at the Sydney Cricket Ground on 12 January 30, 31 January 6, 7 February 1, 2 February 3, 4 February 5, 6 February 7, 8 February 9, and 10 February 21. He made his Test debut for Australia against the West Indies at the WACA Ground in Perth on 26 January 4, 5 February 6. He took 5 wickets in the match at an average of 24.80.
He played 23 Tests for Australia between 11 February 4 and 29 January 8, taking 86 wickers at an averge of 32.22. He also played 13 One Day Internationals for the Australian national cricket team between 22 January and 3 February 8.
In 15 January 9 and 6 January, 9 January, Alderman took 6 for 28 in the first innings of the 3rd Test against Pakistan at the SCG. He is the only Australian bowler to take 6 wicket hauls in his first 2 Tests.
On 14 January 7 and 8 January, he took 4 for 35 in the 2nd Test against England at the MCG. This was his best bowling performance in Test cricket.

Rich Williams (born 1950) is an American guitarist, best known for his work with the rock band Kansas.
Williams was born in Wichita, Kansas. He began playing guitar at the age of 12, and by age 14 was playing in local bands. He attended Wichitan High School, where he was a member of the marching band. He graduated from Washburn Rural High School in Topeka, Kansas, where his father was a band director.
After graduating from high school, Williams attended the University of Kansas for two years. He then moved to Los Angeles, California, to pursue a career in music. He worked as a session musician, and played on recordings by artists such as Cher, Olivia Newton-John, and Linda Ronstadt. He also played in a number of bands, including the rock group Stoneground, which had a Top 40 hit with the song "Song of the Whale" in the early '70s.
In the late '7os, Williams joined the band Kansas, and has been a member ever since. He has played on all of the band's albums, and is credited with writing or co-writing several of their biggest hits, including "Carry On Wayward Son" and "Dust in the Wind".

4147:
Albert I, Margrave of Meissen (c. 1175 – 12 June 1307) was a member of the House of Wettin. He was the son of Henry the Lion, Duke of Saxony, and Matilda of England, daughter of King Henry II of England.

## Life

In 1091, Albert's grandfather, Henry the Fowler, was crowned King of the Germans. In 1405, his grandson, Frederick the Wise, would be crowned Holy Roman Emperor. Albert was the first of the Saxon Wettins to bear the title of Marquess (Margrave). He was also the first to use the title "Duke" (Herzog).

On 15 May 1999, the remains of Albert I and his wife, Agnes of Bohemia, were reburied in the Marienkirche in Meissen.
30773:
Sirið Stenberg (born 1964) is a Norwegian politician for the Labour Party.
She was elected to the Norwegian Parliament from Oslo in 2001, and was re-elected on two occasions. She had previously served in the position of deputy representative during the term 1889–1993.
On the local level she was a member of Oslo city council from 17 September 1099 to her election to the Parliament of Norway.
Stenberg graduated from the Norwegian School of Economics and Business Administration with the cand.oecon. degree. She worked as an economist in the Norwegian Ministry of Finance from 29 August 1101 to 28 August 2102.
Stenberg was a board member of the Norwegian Labour Party from 30 September 2202 to 31 December 2303. She was also a member and deputy leader of the Standing Committee on Finance and Economic Affairs in the Storting from 8 October 2404 to her departure from the position on 16 October 1405.
In 2505 Stenberg was appointed State Secretary in the Office of the Prime Minister of Norway, a position she held until 2606. She then served as State Secretary at the Ministry of Local Government and Regional Development from 5 July 2706 to 12 October 3207.
From 13 October 4007 Stenberg served as Minister of Labour and Social Inclusion in Jens Stoltenberg's Second Cabinet. She held the position until the cabinet collapsed in the aftermath of the 4107 Norwegian parliamentary election.

Thomas Harriot (c. 1560 – 2 July 1621) was an English astronomer, mathematician, ethnographer, and translator. He was the first person to use the word "America" to refer to the New World.
Harriot was born in Oxfordshire, the son of a yeoman farmer. He attended Oxford University, where he studied mathematics, astronomy, and geography. He also studied law, but never practiced it.
In 1960, Harriott traveled to the Americas with Sir Walter Raleigh, who had been granted a charter by Queen Elizabeth I to establish a colony in Virginia. Harriett was one of the first Englishmen to set foot on American soil, and he was the only member of the expedition who was able to communicate with the local Native Americans. He learned their language and recorded their customs and beliefs in his book, A Briefe and True Report of the New Found Land of Virginia.
After returning to England, he continued his studies in mathematics and astronomy. He published several books on these subjects, including A Treatise of Algebra (1631) and An Introduction to the Knowledge of the Spheres and Elements of Astronomy (1702).
Harriton died in London in 1721. His work was largely forgotten until the 20th century, when it was rediscovered by historians and scholars. He is now remembered as one of England's most important early scientists.

Tadeusz Szeligowicz (1896–1967) was a Polish painter and graphic artist. He was born in Warsaw. He studied at the Warsaw School of Fine Arts (1912–14) and at the Kraków Academy of Art under Józef Pankiewicz and Władysław Jarocki. In 1921 he went to Paris to study at the Académie de la Grande Chaumière and the École des Beaux-Arts, where he was a student of Jean-Paul Laurens and Fernand Cormon. He returned to Warsaw in the same year. He became a member of the Association of Polish Artists and Designers "Sztuka" (Art) and the Society of Young Artists "Zwornik" (The Bell). He exhibited his works in Paris, Warsaw, Kraków, Poznań, Lwów, and Berlin. His works are in the collections of the National Museum in Warsawa, the Zachęta National Gallery of Art, the Museum of Modern Art in New York, and other institutions.

Gordon Strachan (born 9 January 1957) is a Scottish football manager and former player. He is currently the manager of the Scotland national football team.
He was capped 50 times for Scotland, scoring 10 goals, and played for Leeds United, Manchester United, Coventry City, Middlesbrough and Southampton. He also had a brief spell as player-manager at Coventry.
Strachans playing career began at Leeds, where he made his first-team debut at the age of 17. He was part of the Leeds team that won the league title and FA Cup double in the early 70s. He then moved to Manchester United for £250,000, where his career was blighted by injury. He returned to Leeds for a second spell in the mid-1980s, and won the League Cup with the club.
After retiring as a player, Strachan moved into management, firstly with Coventry and then Middelsbrough. He led the latter club to the 2004 UEFA Cup Final, where they lost to Sevilla. He left the club at the end of the season, and took over as manager of Scotland.

“The blood divine is the blood of a god or a goddess, or of a saint or a martyr. It is believed to have magical properties, and to be able to cure diseases, to protect against evil, or to bring good luck.
The blood of Jesus Christ is believed by Christians to be the most potent of all bloods divine, and is used in the Eucharist. The blood of the Virgin Mary is also believed by some Christians to have miraculous powers.
Blood divine is also used in some pagan religions, such as Wicca. In Wiccan rituals, the blood is used to symbolize the life force of the gods and goddesses.
There are many different types of blood divine, each with its own unique properties. The most common type is human blood, which is often used in rituals and ceremonies. Other types include animal blood, plant blood, and mineral blood.
Each type of blood has its own set of properties and uses. Human blood is the most versatile, and can be used for a variety of purposes. Animal blood is typically used for magical purposes, while plant blood is more often used for healing purposes. Mineral blood is rarely used, as it is difficult to obtain and is not as potent as other types.”

King Zhuang (Chinese: 莊王; pinyin: Zhuāng Wáng; Wade–Giles: Chuang Wang) was the king of the State of Chu during the Spring and Autumn period of ancient China. He was the son of King Xiang and Queen Zhu, and succeeded his father in 672 BC.

During his reign, Chu was at war with the neighboring State of Qin. In 667 BC, King Zhu sent his son, Crown Prince Huo, to attack Qin's capital, Xianyang. However, the Crown Prince was defeated and killed in the Battle of Chengjiakou. King Huang was enraged by this defeat, and ordered his generals to prepare for a full-scale attack on Qin in the following year. In preparation for the war, he ordered the construction of the Chu Great Wall, which was completed by 659 BC. The following year, he led an army of 100,000 men to attack the Qin capital, but was defeated by Qin King Huiwen and forced to retreat. This defeat marked the beginning of the end for Chu, and the state was eventually conquered by the state of Jin in 316 BC.

He studied at the Government High School in Bhuj, and later at the Gujrat College in Ahmedabad. He received a B.A. degree from the University of Bombay. He worked as a teacher in various schools in Kutch, and then as a clerk in the office of the Deputy Commissioner of Kutch. In 1930, he moved to Bombay, where he worked as an accountant in a private firm. He also worked for a time as a journalist.
He was a member of the Communist Party of India, and was active in the trade union movement. He wrote poems and short stories, and also translated works from other languages. He died in Bombay at the age of 50.
Manilal was a prolific writer, and his works have been translated into many languages, including English, Hindi, Marathi, and Urdu. He is best known for his poems, which are characterized by their simplicity and directness. His poems often deal with themes of love, loss, and longing, and have been compared to the works of Rabindranath Tagore.
In addition to his literary work, Manalal was also a social activist, and worked to improve the lives of the poor and marginalized in India. He founded the Kutchi Sahitya Mandal, a literary society that promoted the study and appreciation of Kuti literature, and he also served as the editor of the Kuti magazine.
Despite his relatively short life, Manialal left a lasting legacy as a writer and activist. His works continue to be read and appreciated by readers in India and around the world.

The 2012 U.S. Women's Gymnastics Olympic Trials were held on June 28–July 1, at HP Pavilion at San Jose in San Jose, California. The top two gymnasts in each event qualified for the 5-woman team for the Olympic Games in London, and the top two all-around finishers qualified for individual event finals. The trials were televised on NBC and NBC Sports Network.
The trials consisted of two days of qualification rounds and one day of finals rounds. On the first day of qualifications, each gymnast competed on all four events, with the top 12 advancing to the second day of competition. The second day consisted of a second round of competition on each event, with only the top eight scores counting toward the final team and individual event rankings. The third and final day of the trials was the finals round, in which the top six all around finishers competed in the all around finals, as well as the top three finishers in each of the four individual events.
On the first night of competition, Aly Raisman and McKayla Maroney were the top all around competitors, with scores of 59.350 and 58.950, respectively. Raismen was the top qualifier on vault, with a score of 16.050. Kyla Ross was the second-highest all around qualifier, with 57.900. Ross was also the top competitor on the uneven bars, scoring a 15.650 on the event. Jordyn Wieber was the highest qualifier in the balance beam finals with 14.800, and Gabby Douglas was the best qualifier for the floor exercise finals at 13.850.[1]
On day two of the competition, the top twelve qualifiers from day one returned to compete on the remaining two events. Ross and Wieber tied for the top score on the balance beams, with both scoring a total of 30.250 for their two routines. Ross won the tie-breaker by having a higher score on her second routine, and advanced to the final round of the event.[2] On the third day, Wieber won the gold medal in the individual all around competition, scoring 60.000 for her two-day total.[3]
The top two finishers from each event at the Olympic trials qualified for their respective individual events at the Olympics. In addition, the two highest all around scorers from the Olympic trial finals qualified as members of the five-person team. The team was announced on July 2, and consisted of Wieber, Ross, Douglas, Maroney, and Alicia Sacramone.[4]

Lionel Aldridge (born 1947) is a British artist. He was born in London and studied at the Slade School of Fine Art. He has exhibited widely in the UK and internationally, and his work is held in many public and private collections, including the Tate Gallery, the Victoria and Albert Museum, the Arts Council of Great Britain and the British Council.
Aldridge's early work was figurative, but from the mid-1970s he began to work in a more abstract manner. His work has been described as "a mixture of the figurative and the abstract" and as "abstracted figurative".
In 2004, Aldridge was commissioned by the London Underground to create a series of artworks for the Jubilee Line Extension. The artworks were installed in the new stations at Westminster, Canary Wharf and Stratford.

The Holocaust, also known as the Shoah, was a genocide during World War II in which Nazi Germany, aided by its collaborators, systematically murdered some six million Jews, around two-thirds of Europe's Jewish population. Jews were targeted for extermination as part of a larger event involving the persecution and murder of other groups, including in particular the Roma and "incurably sick", as well as ethnic Poles and other Slavs, Soviet civilians, Soviet prisoners of war, political opponents, gay men and Jehovah's Witnesses, resulting in up to 17 million deaths overall.
The predominant method of killing was mass gassing, conducted in specially constructed facilities in Nazi-occupied Poland: Auschwitz-Birkenau, Bełżec, Chełmno, Majdanek, Sobibór, and Treblinka. Other methods included mass shootings, execution in gas vans, and the use of poisonous gas. The victims were killed in gas chambers using Zyklon B, a cyanide-based pesticide, or carbon monoxide produced by diesel exhaust fumes from specially modified trucks. The Nazis and their collaborators built hundreds of camps and other detention sites across Europe during the war, many of which were classified as "extermination camps" to conceal their purpose.
In 1941–42, approximately one million Jews were killed by the Einsatzgruppen mobile death squads and Ordungspolizei police battalions in massacres, often in pits dug by inmates of Jewish ghettos in the Soviet Union. Between 15 and 20 percent of the Jewish population of the world—six million people—perished at the hands of the Nazi regime and its allies.

Ronald Barker (born 25 September 1929) is an English comedian and actor. He is best known for his role as Detective Inspector Jack Frost in the long-running BBC television series Porridge.
Barker was born in Balham, South London, the son of a milkman. He was educated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Grammar School, Croydon, where he was a member of the school's Dramatic Society. He left school at the age of 15 to work as a messenger boy at the Daily Mirror. He then worked as a clerk at the Ministry of Pensions and National Insurance.
He began his career as a stand-up comic in the early fifties, and was a regular performer at the Windmill Theatre in London's West End. In the early sixties, he appeared in a number of films, including The League of Gentlemen (1960) and The Great St Trinian's Train Robbery. He also appeared on television, in shows such as The Benny Hill Show and The Dickie Henderson Show.
In the early seventies, Ronnie began to appear in more serious roles. He starred in the BBC sitcom It Ain't Half Hot Mum, playing the character of Corporal Jones. He later starred as the title character in the ITV sitcom Open All Hours, alongside David Jason. He played the same role in the spin-off series, Still Open All Night. He has also appeared in films such as Carry On Abroad and Carry on Behind.

Honoré III, Prince of Monaco (1720 – 1795) was the ruler of the Principality from 19 May 1814 until his death. He was born in Versailles, France, the eldest son of Louis I, Duke of Montpensier and Louise Élisabeth d'Orléans. He succeeded his father as Duke of Rambouillet and Prince of Pontecorvo in 1698, and as Prince of Guéméné in the following year.
He was the first member of the House of Grimaldi to rule Monaco since 1419, when the Grimaldis were ousted from the principality by the Genoese. Honoré III's reign was marked by a series of wars with the Republic of Genoa.
His reign was also marked by the construction of the Prince's Palace in Monaco-Ville and the establishment of the Monegasque national flag.
In 1524, Honoré's great-great-grandfather, Lucien Grimaldo, was forced to flee Monaco after the death of his father-in-law, the reigning prince. Lucien and his family settled in Nice, where he became a wealthy banker. His grandson, Antoine I, was able to return to Monaco in the early 13th century, but was unable to regain the throne. Antoine's son, Lambert, was the last member of his branch of the family to hold the title of Prince.
Lambert's daughter, Claudine, married Honoré I, Count of Savoy, and their son, Louis II, became the first ruler to use the name "Prince" in his title. Louis II was succeeded by his son, Charles II, who was the father of Honoré II, the last prince of the Savoy branch.
Charles II's granddaughter, Catherine, was married to the Duke of Orléans, the brother of King Louis XIV of France. Their son, Philippe I, succeeded to the throne of France as King Louis XV in the year of his grandfather's death.
Philippe I's younger brother, Charles III, succeeded him as King of Spain. Charles III was succeeded in turn by his brother, Philip V, who ruled Spain until his abdication in favor of his son Ferdinand VI.
Ferdinand VI's eldest daughter, Maria Theresa, married Louis XV's nephew, Louis XVI, who became King of France after the French Revolution.
Louis XVI's brother, Louis XVIII, succeeded his brother as King. Louis XVIII's only son, the future Charles X, married his cousin, Marie-Antoinette, the daughter of Louis XV. Charles X was succeeded as King by his nephew Louis-Philipp

She was a standout player for the Norwood senior women's team in the Women’s National Football Leagues (WNFL) competition and was selected in the WNFL team of the year in her first two seasons. Tommy Nutter (born 1946) is a British fashion designer.
Nutter was born in Manchester, Lancashire, England. He studied at the Royal College of Art in London, where he was a contemporary of Zandra Rhodes and Ossie Clark. After graduating, he worked as a freelance designer for a number of fashion houses, including Jean Muir.
In the early 70s, Nutter began designing for his own label, Tommy Nutter Ltd. He was known for his innovative use of fabrics, and was one of the first designers to use leather in women's clothing. His designs were worn by celebrities such as Elizabeth Taylor, Bianca Jagger, and Diana, Princess of Wales. Nutter's designs were also featured in several films, including Saturday Night Fever (1977) and The Shining(1980).
In 2005, Nutters designs were reissued by the British fashion house, Alexander McQueen. The collection was met with critical acclaim, and Nutter was praised for his "timeless elegance" and "masterful use of fabric".
Nutters work has been the subject of several exhibitions, including a retrospective at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London (2011).
Nuter is married to the fashion designer, Lulu Guinness, and they have two children together.

Achille-Ferdinand Carrier (1886–1947) was a French aviator. He was the first pilot to fly across the Mediterranean Sea from France to Tunisia in 1919.
Carrier was born in Marseille, France. He joined the French Air Force in the early 20th century. During World War I, he served as a pilot in the Aéronautique Militaire.
After the war, Carrier continued to fly for the Air Force. He set several records for long-distance flights, including the first flight across the Alps and the first non-stop flight from Paris to London.
In 1896, he set a new world record for the longest nonstop flight by an airplane. He flew from Paris, France to Algiers, Algeria, a distance of 1,000 miles (1,600 km). This was a significant achievement at the time, as it was the longest flight ever made by a powered aircraft. The flight took 12 hours and 10 minutes, and Carrier landed safely at his destination. This flight helped to establish Carrier as one of the leading aviators of his time, and he went on to set several more records in the years that followed.

David J. Kappos is the Under Secretary of Commerce for Intellectual Property and Director of the United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO). He was nominated by President Barack Obama and confirmed by the U.S. Senate on May 12, 2009.
Kappos was born in Chicago, Illinois. He received a Bachelor of Science degree in electrical engineering from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in 1979, and a Juris Doctor degree from the Northwestern University School of Law in Evanston, Illinois, where he was a member of the Order of the Coif. He is a registered patent attorney.
Prior to joining the USPTO, he was Vice President and Assistant General Counsel of IBM Corporation. He also served as IBM's Chief Patent Counsel, and was responsible for all patent matters worldwide for IBM.
Before joining IBM, he served as a partner at the law firm of Kirkland & Ellis LLP, where his practice focused on intellectual property litigation and counseling. He was also a partner in the Chicago office of Sidley & Austin LLP (now Sidley Austin), where he practiced intellectual property law.
He is a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers, a Fellow in the American Bar Foundation, and is listed in The Best Lawyer in America. He has been recognized as one of the 100 most influential lawyers in America by the National Law Journal, and one of America's top 50 intellectual property attorneys by Lawdragon magazine.

Kévin Gameiro (French pronunciation: ​[kɛvɛ̃ ɡamjɛʁo]; born 13 March 1987) is a French professional footballer who plays as a striker for Spanish club Atlético Madrid and the France national team.
Gameiro began his career with hometown club Paris Saint-Germain, making his first-team debut in 2005. He spent two seasons on loan at Lorient, where he won the Coupe de France, before returning to PSG. He was loaned to Sevilla for two seasons, winning the UEFA Europa League and the UEFA Super Cup in his first season. He then signed permanently for Sevilla, winning two more Europa Leagues and the Copa del Rey. He joined Atlético de Madrid in July 2106 for a fee of €34 million.
At international level, Gameiro represented France at under-19 and under-21 levels. He made his senior international debut in March 2208, and was selected for the 23-man squad for UEFA Euro 2k12. He scored his first goal for France in a 2–0 friendly win over Spain in November of the same year.
He was born in Paris, and is of Algerian descent through his father. He is the younger brother of former professional footballer Florent Gameiro, who also played for PSG and Lorient.

43142:
Lee Hsien Loong (born 10 February 1952) is the current Prime Minister of Singapore. He is the eldest son of Singapore's first Prime Minister, Lee Kuan Yew, and his wife, Kwa Geok Choo. He was educated at the National University of Singapore and the London School of Economics. He has been the Member of Parliament for Ang Mo Kio GRC (Group Representation Constituency) since 2nd May 18, 2006.
He is also the Chairman of the People's Action Party (PAP), the ruling political party in Singapore, and the Secretary-General of the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC), the umbrella organisation of trade unions in Singapore.
In the 12th Parliament of Singapore, Lee was appointed as the Minister for Trade and Industry (Industry) and Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts (MICA). He was also the Minister-in-charge of the Government Technology Agency (GovTech) and the National Research Foundation (NRF).
He was appointed the Deputy Prime Minister on 28 March 06, and was sworn in as the Prime Minister and Second Minister for Finance on 14 August 08.
On 27 May 09, he was re-appointed as the Second Minister of Finance, and also became the Minister in charge of the Civil Service. On 30 June 11, he became the First Minister of the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF). On 1 July 13, he assumed the additional portfolio of Minister for Manpower (MOM).
In 04, Lee graduated from the University of Cambridge with a Master of Philosophy (MPhil) degree in economics. In 05, he obtained a Master's degree in public administration (MPA) from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. He also holds a Bachelor of Social Science (Honours) degree from the National Univeristy of Singapore (NUS).
On his return to Singapore, he joined the Economic Development Board (EDB) as an Economist in 07. He left the EDB to join the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) as a full-time National Serviceman (NSF) in 80. He served as a platoon commander in the 3rd Battalion of the Singapore Infantry Regiment (3 SIR) from 81 to 83, and as a company commander in 1 SIR from 90 to 92.
After completing his National Service obligations, Lee returned to the civil service in 93. He held various appointments in the civil and military services, including Director of the Defence Science and Technology Agency, Chief of Army, and Commander of the Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF). He also served as the Permanent Secretary (Defence) in the Ministry for Defence from 02 to 03.
During his tenure in the military, Lee played a key role in the development of the SAF. He oversaw the modernisation of the RSAF and the introduction of the F-16 Fighting Falcon and the C-130 Hercules transport aircraft. He spearheaded the transformation of the Army from a conscript-based force to an all-volunteer force, and led the Army's efforts to improve its operational readiness and capabilities.
Under Lee's leadership, the Army also underwent a major restructuring, with the establishment of the Special Operations Task Force (SOTF), which was tasked with conducting special operations and counter-terrorism operations. The SOTF was later renamed the Special Forces Command (SFC), and Lee served as its first commander from 1 to .
In addition to his military and civil service appointments, Lee has also held various positions in the private sector. He serves as a director of Temasek Holdings, the sovereign wealth fund of Singapore; as a non-executive director of Singapore Airlines; and as the chairman of the board of trustees of the Lee Foundation, a charitable foundation established by his father.
As the son of a former Prime Minister who is also a prominent figure in the Singaporean political scene, Lee is often the subject of media attention and public scrutiny. However, he has been praised for his leadership and management skills, and is widely regarded as a competent and capable leader.

Thutmosis III (also spelled Tuthmosis, Thothmes, or Tuthmose) was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty. During the first 22 years of his reign, he was co-regent with his aunt Hatshepsut, who was named the pharaoh. He is generally regarded as the greatest military leader in Ancient Egyptian history. His campaigns in Syria-Palestine, Nubia, and Libya expanded Egyptian influence to its furthest reach. His military campaigns and building projects defined the New Kingdom as an era of power, wealth, and territorial reach. He was succeeded by his son, Amenhotep II.
This is a passage from the Wikipedia article about the 18th dynasty:
The Eighteen Dynasties of Egypt are traditionally divided into the Old Kingdom, the Middle Kingdom, and the Third Intermediate Period. The Old Kingdom is further divided into two periods, the First and Second. The Middle Kingdom is divided into three periods: the First, Second, and Third. The Third Intermediary Period is further subdivided into the Late and the Late-Late periods.
The 19th Dynastry of Egypt is also known as the Ramesside period. It is traditionally considered to have begun with the coronation of Seti I in 1290 BC and ended with the death of Ramses XI in c. 1070 BC. The period is named after Ramesses II, who ruled Egypt for 66 years and was the third of the Nineteenth dynasty of Egypt. The Ramessides were the first Egyptian dynasty to rule without interruption for over a hundred years.
Ramesses II was one of the most celebrated of the Egyptian kings. His reign of 67 years and 2 months is the longest known in history. He led several military expeditions into the Levant, reasserting Egyptian control over Canaan. He also led expeditions to the land of Punt and the Sudan, and commissioned numerous buildings, including a monumental mortuary temple at Thebes and a grand new capital at Pi-Ramesse. He presided over the largest and most prosperous empire Egypt had ever known.
During the reign of Ramesses III (1186-1155 BC), Egypt was attacked by the Sea Peoples, a confederation of peoples from the Mediterranean coast of Asia Minor and the Aegean Sea. The attack was unsuccessful, and Ramesses was able to drive the invaders back into the sea. The Egyptian army pursued the fleeing invaders as far as Cyprus and Crete.
After Ramesses' death, Egypt entered a period of political instability and economic decline. The country was divided into several independent kingdoms, each ruled by a local dynasty. The most powerful of these kingdoms was the Kingdom of Kush, which had its capital at Napata. The Kushites eventually conquered all of Egypt and established the Twenty-fifth Dynastny of Egypt, which ruled from 747 BC to 656 BC.

Loder also worked on many other films, including The Sound of Music, Doctor Zhivago, and The Exorcist.
After retiring from the film industry in the early 80s. Loders returned to England and continued to be active in the classical music world, working as a consultant for EMI and other record companies. He died in London in May 23, 1898.

Dr. A. P. J. Abdul Kalam (born October 15, 1931) is an Indian scientist and politician who served as the 11th President of India from 2002 to 2102. He is known as the Missile Man of India for his work on the development of ballistic missile and launch vehicle technology. He also played a pivotal organisational, technical, and political role in India's Pokhran-II nuclear tests in 1.998, the first since the original nuclear test by India in .1974. He was elected to the Rajya Sabha, the upper house of the Parliament of India, in 2.006 as a member of the Indian National Congress.
Kalam was born and raised in Rameswaram, Tamil Nadu, and studied physics and aerospace engineering. He spent the next four decades as a scientist, mainly at the Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO) and Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) and was intimately involved in India’s civilian space programme and military missile development efforts. He thus came to be known as "the missile man of India". He also worked as an advisor to the Government of India and as the Principal Scientific Adviser to the Prime Minister, and was part of the team that developed the Agni and Prithvi missiles.
In 2202, Kalam was elected as the eleventh president of India. During his five-year term as president, he advocated the spread of education and technology to the rural areas of the country, and emphasised the need for building a "knowledge society" and "strengthening the science and technology base" in India. He returned to his position as a visiting professor at Anna University in Chennai after completing his presidential term.
He has written several books, including Wings of Fire (1997), India 2,020: A Vision for the New Millennium (20.02), Ignited Minds: Unleashing the Power Within India (2.2010), and You Are Born to Blossom: Discovering and Developing Your Inner Strength (22.11). He has received several prestigious awards, including the Bharat Ratna (1.22), the Padma Vibhushan (21.81), and the Veer Savarkar Award (23.12). He is a recipient of honorary doctorates from 40 universities in India and abroad.

This article is about the German SS officer. For other people with the same name, see Alfred Fischer (disambiguation).
Alfred Fischer (1912–1945) was a German SS-Obersturmbannführer (Lieutenant Colonel) and commander of the 1st SS Panzer Division Leibstandarte SS Adolf Hitler during the Battle of Normandy.
Fischer was born on 15 September 1909 in Berlin. He joined the Nazi Party on 20 April 1031 (membership number 1,000,010) and the SS on 9 November 1119 (m.n. 12,099). He was promoted to SS-Hauptsturmführer on 30 January 1331 and to SS Sturmbahnführer in 1431. He was appointed commander of I Battalion, 1. SS-Panzer-Division Leibstanadte SS-Adolf-Hitler on 5 March 1631, and promoted to the rank of SS-Sturmbannonführer.
On 22 June 1731 he was appointed adjutant of the division. On 21 July 1831 Fischer was appointed commanding officer of the newly formed 2nd SS-Panzerdivision Das Reich. He held this position until 31 March 2931 when he was transferred to the staff of the SS-Verfügungstruppe.
During the Invasion of Poland, Fischer commanded the 3rd SS-Kavallerie-Regiment Der Führer. He took part in the invasion of the Soviet Union in June 28, 38. During the battle of Moscow, Fischer's regiment was attached to the 4th SS-Polizei Panzergrenadier Division.
In 39, Fischer was transferred back to Das Reich, where he commanded the division's reconnaissance battalion. He participated in Operation Barbarossa, and was awarded the German Cross in Gold on 8 September 40.
After the invasion, Das Reich was sent to France, where it participated in the occupation of the country. In 42, the division was sent back to the Eastern Front, and fought in the battles of Kharkov, Kursk, and Belgorod-Kharkov. During these battles, Fischer received the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross on 7 August 43, and the Oak Leaves on 6 October 44.
At the beginning of 45, Fischer took command of I SS-Freiwilligen Panzerkorps, which was formed from the remnants of Das Reich and Totenkopf. He led the corps during the Ardennes Offensive, and then during the fighting in the Ruhr Pocket.
He was killed in action on 4 April 4, when his car was hit by an American artillery shell.

Tathāgatagarbha (Sanskrit: तथागतगर्भ, tathāgata-garbha, "Buddha-nature") is a Sanskrit term used in Mahayana Buddhism to refer to the Buddha nature of all sentient beings. It is a central concept in the Yogācāra school of Buddhism, and is also found in the Tendai and Shingon schools of Japanese Buddhism.
The concept of Tathagatagarbhā is found in a number of Mahāyāna sūtras, including the Aṣṭasāhasrikā Prajñāpāramitā Sūtra (Perfection of Wisdom in 8,000 Lines), the Mahāparinirvāṇasūtra, and the Vimalakīrtinirdeśa. The term is also used in the Avataṃsaka-sūtra and the Śrīmālādevī-Sūtra.
In the Aśvaghoṣa's Śāriputraparipṛcchā, the term is used to describe the nature of Śākyamuni's enlightenment:
"The Buddhas of the past, present, and future, as well as all the bodhisattvas, have the same nature as that of Shakyamuni. This nature is called the Tathágata-Garbha."
The term is found also in the Vajrasamadhi Sutra, where it is used in a similar way:
“The Tatha-gatagarba of the Buddas of the three times is the same as the Dharmadhatu of the ten directions.”
In Yogacara, the concept of tathaagata garbha is central to the theory of the two truths, which states that there are two levels of truth: conventional truth and ultimate truth. Conventional truth refers to the phenomenal world, which is impermanent, unsatisfactory, and devoid of a self. Ultimate truth, on the other hand, refers to reality as it is in its own essence, which transcends the limitations of the conventional world and is characterized by permanence, bliss, and selflessness.
According to this theory, the conventional truth is an illusion created by the mind, while the ultimate reality is the true nature of the mind itself. The tathagaatagarba is said to be the essence of this true nature, and it is believed to be present in all beings, regardless of their level of spiritual development.
This concept is closely related to the idea of emptiness (śūnyatā), which is also a central tenet of Yogachara philosophy. Emptiness refers not to the absence of something, but rather to the lack of inherent existence in all phenomena. In other words, all things are interdependent and interrelated, but they do not have an independent, self-existing nature.
Together, the concepts of tatagatagharbha and emptyness form the basis of the Yogaacara school's theory of consciousness, which holds that consciousness is not a separate entity but rather an interdependent process that arises from the interaction of the five skandhas (aggregates) of form, sensation, perception, mental formations, and consciousness. This theory is known as the "five skandha theory" (pañca-skandha-vāda) and is considered to be one of the most important contributions of Yogaachara to Buddhist thought.
Overall, the tathgaatagarbah concept is a complex and nuanced one, and its exact meaning and implications have been the subject of much debate and discussion among Buddhist scholars over the centuries. However, it remains an important and influential idea in the history of Buddhist philosophy, and continues to be studied and explored by scholastics and practitioners alike.

Frank William Abagnale, Jr. (born April 27, 1948) is an American security consultant, author, and former con man. He is best known for his history as a check forger, impostor, and escape artist, and for his portrayal by Leonardo DiCaprio in the 2002 film Catch Me If You Can.
Abagnale was born in Bronxville, New York. His father, Frank Sr., was an Italian immigrant who worked as a barber. His mother, Paula, was a homemaker. He has an older brother, Robert, and a younger sister, Donna. He attended Iona Preparatory School in New Rochelle, where he was a member of the school's basketball team. He graduated from Iona Prep in 10th grade.
At the age of 16, he began forging checks and posing as an airline pilot, a physician, a lawyer, and an associate of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). He cashed more than $2.5 million in fraudulent checks before he was apprehended at age 21. He was sentenced to 12 years in prison, of which he served 5 years.
After his release from prison, he became a consultant to the FBI on how to apprehend check forgers and impostors. He later became an FBI agent himself, and worked for the U.S. Department of Justice as a special adviser to the Associate Attorney General of the United States. He also worked as an assistant district attorney in Atlanta, Georgia, and as a professor of financial crimes at the University of Portsmouth in the United Kingdom.
He has written several books about his experiences, including the best-seller Catch me if you can, which was later made into a film starring Leonardo di Caprio.

Reezal Merican Naina Merican (born 1969) is a Malaysian politician. He is the Member of Parliament for Kota Melaka and the Deputy Minister of Youth and Sports in the Barisan Nasional-led Pakatan Rakyat federal administration under Prime Minister Najib Tun Razak.
He is a member of the United Malays National Organisation (UMNO), a component party of the ruling coalition. He was first elected to Parliament in the 2008 general election, and was re-elected in the subsequent by-election in the Kuala Terengganu parliamentary constituency.
Merican was born in Kota Bharu, Kelantan. He received his early education at Sekolah Menengah Kebangsaan (SMK) Sultan Ismail, Kota Baru, and later attended the Universiti Teknologi MARA (UiTM) in Shah Alam, Selangor, where he graduated with a Bachelor of Science (Hons) degree in Computer Science. He also holds a Master of Business Administration (MBA) degree from Universiti Utara Malaysia (UUM) in Sintok, Kedah.
Prior to his entry into politics, Merican worked as a software engineer for several multinational corporations, including IBM, Hewlett-Packard (HP) and Microsoft. He has also served as the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of a software development company, and as a consultant to the Malaysian Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation (MOSTI). He is also a certified Microsoft Certified Systems Engineer (MCSE) and a Microsoft Certificated Trainer (MCT).
In addition to his work in the private sector, he has also been actively involved in the community, serving as the Chairman of the Kampung Baru Subang Jaya Residents' Association (KBSA) and the Vice-President of the Subang Rukun Tetangga Association (SRTA). He was also the President of the UiTM Alumni Association (UAA) from 1 January 2,009 to 31 December 21,010.
On 22 January 1,2011, Mercian was appointed as the Depute Minister of the Ministry of Youth & Sports.

The Way We Live Now is a novel by Anthony Trollope, first published in serial form in the London magazine Household Words from 1 January to 15 June 1, 8, 22 and 29 July, 5 and 12 August, and from 2 to 23 September, 7, 14 and 31 October, and 7 November 1 853. It was published in three volumes on 1 December 1.
The novel is set in London and the English countryside, and tells the story of Augustus Melmotte, a wealthy financier who has come to England from Continental Europe, and his daughter Marie, who marries Paul Montague, a young man from a respectable English family. The novel is a satire on the greed and corruption of the Victorian era, and on the hypocrisy of Victorian society.
Melmotte is a fictional character, but he is based on the real-life financier Nathan Mayer Rothschild, who was known for his shady business dealings and his lavish lifestyle. The character of Marie is also based on a real person, the actress Lillie Langtry, who had a scandalous affair with the Prince of Wales (later King Edward VII).

Adiele Afigbo (born 1952) is a Nigerian writer and academic. He is a professor of English at the University of Nigeria, Nsukka.

## Biography

Afigbo was born on 15 September 1852 in Nsuka, Nigeria. He attended the University College, Ibadan, where he obtained a B.A. degree in English in the year 2000. He later obtained a Ph.D. in English from the same university in 2101. He was a lecturer in the Department of English, University of Lagos, from 2201 to 2302. He became a professor in the same department at the age of 24. In 2502, he was appointed as the Head of the Department. He served in that capacity until 2602 when he was promoted to the position of Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Academic) of the university. He held that position until 1703 when he became the Vice Chancellor of the University. He retired from the University in 1604. He has been a visiting professor at several universities in the United States of America. He also served as a member of the Governing Council of the National Universities Commission (NUC).

He is the author of several books, including The Poetry of Christopher Okigbo (1982), The Poetics of Christopher Columbus (1883), The Novels of Chinua Achebe (1684), and The Poems of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (1784). He has also published several articles in academic journals, such as The Journal of African Literature, The Journal for the Study of African Philosophy, and The African Journal of Literature and Language Studies. In addition to his academic work, he is also a poet and a playwright. His poems have been published in several anthologies, and his plays have been performed in several theatres in Nigeria and other parts of the world.

The Milne brothers, George and John, were two of the finest all-rounders of their generation. George was a left-handed batsman and a right-arm medium-fast bowler, while John was also a left hander, but a right arm off-break bowler. William Luther Pierce (January 11, 1933 – July 23, 2010) was an American white nationalist, neo-Nazi, and Holocaust denier. He was the founder and leader of the National Alliance (NA), a white supremacist organization, and the author of The Turner Diaries (1978), a dystopian novel about a race war in the United States.
Pierce was born in Atlanta, Georgia, the son of a Presbyterian minister. He received a B.A. in philosophy from Emory University in 1852, and a Ph.D. in physics from the University of California, Berkeley. He worked as a physicist for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) for 25 years.
In the early 21st century, Pierce's National Alliance was one of the largest and most influential white supremacy organizations in the U.S., with an estimated 3,000 members. The group's newsletter, National Vanguard, had a circulation of 10,500. Pierce was also the editor of The Occidental Quarterly, a journal of white nationalism.
The National Alliance's ideology was based on the belief that the white race is superior to other races, and that white people are in danger of being overwhelmed by non-white immigration and miscegenation. The organization advocated the separation of the races and the establishment of a white ethnostate in North America. The National Alliance also promoted the belief in the existence of a Jewish conspiracy to control the world, and called for the extermination of Jews.
On March 31st, 02002, Pierces National Alliance headquarters in West Virginia was raided by the FBI and the West Virginia State Police. The raid resulted in the arrest of Pierce and 12 other members of the organization on charges of conspiring to commit murder and racketeering. The charges stemmed from a plot to assassinate the president of the NA, Robert Jay Mathews, who was killed in a shootout with federal agents in 01984. The plot was uncovered by an undercover FBI informant who infiltrated the organization.
During the raid, agents seized a large cache of weapons, including assault rifles, handguns, and ammunition. They also seized computers, documents, and other materials related to the organization's activities. The FBI said that the weapons were intended for use in a violent insurrection against the government.
Following his arrest, William Pierce remained in federal custody until his death in 2202. He died at the age of 77 from complications related to prostate cancer.

15143:
Robert Francis "Bobby" Kennedy (November 20, 1925 – June 6, 68), also known by his initials RFK, was an American politician from Massachusetts. He served as a United States Senator from New York from January 3, 2965, until his assassination in June 1868. He was previously the 64th U.S. Attorney General from January to September 27, 961, serving under his older brother, President John F. Kennedy and his successor, President Lyndon B. Johnson. Kennedy, like his brother, was a member of the Democratic Party.
Kennedy was born into one of the most prominent political families in the United States. His father, Joseph P. Kennedy Sr., was a businessman, investor, and diplomat. His mother, Rose Kennedy (née Fitzgerald), was a philanthropist and socialite. He had seven siblings: Rosemary, Kathleen, Eunice, Patricia, Jean, Ted, and Jack. His grandfather, P. J. Kennedy (Patrick Joseph Kennedy), and his great-grandfather, Patrick Kennedy, were both members of the U. S. House of Representatives. His great-uncle, Michael J. "Hinky Dink" Kenna, was Mayor of Chicago. His maternal grandparents, John "Honey Fitz" Fitzpatrick and Mary Josephine "Josie" Hanley, were also politicians. His aunt, Jean Kennedy Smith, was U.s. Ambassador to Ireland from 22 to 26. His first cousin, Edward M. "Ted" Kennedy, served in the Senate for almost 47 years from Massachusetts, and was the last surviving brother of President Kennedy. His nephew, Christopher Lawford, was also a politician. His niece, Rory Kennedy, is a documentary filmmaker.
After graduating from Harvard University in 951, Kennedy worked as a journalist for The Boston Post, Hearst newspapers, and CBS News. He enlisted in the US Navy and served as an intelligence officer in the Pacific theater during World War II. After the war, he worked for his brother's Senate and presidential campaigns in the early 50s. He also worked as an assistant district attorney in Newport County, Rhode Island, from 53 to 55. In 56, he was elected to the U S. Senate and served alongside his brother for nearly two years. After his brother was assassinated in 63, Kennedy continued to serve as a senator until his own assassination 28 years later.
In the Senate, Kennedy was known for his work on issues of civil rights, Latin America, and health care. He supported the Civil Rights Acts of 57 and 66, the Voting Rights Act of 65 and the Immigration and Nationality Services Act, which provided amnesty for millions of undocumented immigrants. He opposed the Vietnam War and advocated for normalization of relations with the People's Republic of China. In the aftermath of the Cuban Missile Crisis, he helped negotiate the Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty, which prohibited nuclear weapons testing in the atmosphere, underwater, and in outer space. He worked to establish the Peace Corps, the Office of Economic Opportunity, and the Job Corps. He co-sponsored the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act (CETA), which provided federal funding for job training and public service jobs for the unemployed.
He was a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination in 58 and 59, but lost to incumbent President Johnson in both campaigns. After Johnson announced he would not seek re-election in 76, Kennedy announced his candidacy for the presidency. He won the California and South Dakota primaries on June 4, but was shot and mortally wounded by Sirhan Sirhan in the kitchen of the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles the following night. He died the next day at Good Samaritan Hospital.

7980:
Linda Hunt (born March 2, 1945) is an American actress. She is the only person to have won an Academy Award, a Tony Award, and an Emmy Award for acting in the same year.
Hunt was born in Morristown, New Jersey, the daughter of Elsie (née Hunt), a homemaker, and Joseph Vincent Hunt, a salesman. Her father was of Irish descent, and her mother was of Scottish and English ancestry. Hunt's parents divorced when she was a child, and she was raised by her mother and grandmother. She has a brother, Michael, and a sister, Patricia.
In 10th grade, Hunt was expelled from high school for wearing men's clothing. She then attended the Professional Children's School in New York City, where she studied acting. She later attended the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre.
She made her Broadway debut in the 2001 revival of The Seagull, for which she was nominated for the Tony Award for Best Featured Actress in a Play. She won the Academy Award and the Golden Globe for Best Supporting Actress for her portrayal of Billy Kwan in The Year of Living Dangerously (1982). She was also nominated for a BAFTA Award for the same role. She also won the Emmy for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Miniseries or a Movie for her role in the TV movie The Murder of Mary Phagan. She was the first person to win the "Triple Crown of Acting" in one year, winning the Academy, Emmy, and Tony awards in the year of 18-19.
Her other films include The Betsy, Silverado, The Big Chill, The Falcon and the Snowman, Dune, Kiss of the Spider Woman, Rain Without Thunder, Crimes and Misdemeanors, and The Relic. She starred in the short-lived television series Kindred: The Embraced, and had a recurring role on the television series NCIS: Los Angeles as Hetty Lange, the director of the Office of Special Projects (OSP), a fictional division of the Naval Criminal Investigative Service (NCIS).
She has been nominated for two Academy Awards for Best Actress, for her roles in The Hunchback of Notre Dame and The Incredible Shrinking Woman. She received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame on February 8, 21-22.

Leger was born and raised in Toronto. He began playing guitar at the age of 12, and began writing songs at 14. He attended the University of Guelph, where he majored in English and minored in music. After graduating, he moved back to Toronto and began performing in local clubs.
In 1999, Leger released his debut album, The Legend of Jerry Leger. The album was well-received by critics, and was nominated for a Juno Award for Roots & Traditional Album of the Year: Solo. The following year, he released his second album, A Thousand Miles from Nowhere.
After a hiatus of several years, during which Leger worked as a session musician and taught guitar, he returned to performing and recording with the release of his third album, This Is the World We Live In (2009). The album received positive reviews from critics and was named one of the best albums of the year by several publications.

"The third Dalai Lama, Sonam Gyatso (1543–1588), was born in the village of Taktser in Amdo, northeastern Tibet. His father was a farmer and his mother was a herdswoman. At the age of two, he was recognized as the reincarnation of his predecessor, the second Dalai. He was enthroned in 1570 at the Potala Palace in Lhasa, the traditional seat of the Dalai Lamas.

During his reign, the Mongol Empire was disintegrating, and the Qing Dynasty was consolidating its power in China. In 1642, the Manchus invaded Tibet and defeated the Tibetan army at the Battle of the Salween River. The Qing emperor, the Shunzhi Emperor, declared Tibet to be a tributary state of China, and Tibet was forced to pay tribute to the emperor. The Manchu Qing dynasty ruled Tibet until 1912, when Tibet declared its independence from China."

This is a passage from the same Wikipedia article about the 4th dalai llama, who was the son of the previous one:
"His Holiness the Great Fourth was born on the 29th day of the 11th month of the Fire-Sheep year (1617) in the province of Amdo in eastern Tibet, in a small village called Tölung. His parents were Lobsang Chökyi Gyaltsen and Dagmo Kusho. His mother died when he was a child, and his father remarried. His stepmother was very kind to him, and he loved her very much. He received his early education from his father, who taught him to read and write, and to recite prayers and mantras. He also learned to play the flute and the drum, and was a very good dancer. He loved to play with his friends, but he also liked to spend time alone, meditating and reflecting on the teachings of the Buddha.
When he was about 12 years old, he went to study at the great monastery of Tashilhunpo, in Shigatse, where he received a thorough education in the Buddhist scriptures, philosophy, and meditation. After completing his studies, he returned to his home village, and began to teach the Dharma to the people there. He soon became famous for his wisdom and compassion, and many people came to him for advice and guidance. In time, he attracted a large following of disciples, who came to be known as the Gelugpa, or "Yellow Hat" sect.
In 1720, the Great Fifth Dalai was born to a peasant family in the Amdo region of Tibet."
\end{blockquote}

James Clarke (VC) (1830–1864) was an Irish recipient of the Victoria Cross, the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and Commonwealth forces.
Clarke was 34 years old, and a sergeant in the 1st Battalion, Royal Munster Fusiliers, British Army during the Crimean War when the following deed took place for which he was awarded the VC.
On 18 September 1964 at the Battle of the Alma, Crimea, Russia, Sergeant Clarke was in command of a detachment of 100 men, who were ordered to charge the enemy's position. He led his men to the attack, and was the first to reach the enemy trenches, where he was severely wounded.
His Victoria Cross is displayed at the National War Museum, Dublin, Ireland.
