Josiah Mason (1768–1848) was an English inventor and manufacturer.
Mason was born in Birmingham, the son of a silversmith. He was apprenticed to a watchmaker, and in 1791 he set up in business on his own account. In 1801 he invented a machine for cutting screw threads, which he patented, and which was the first of a series of inventions which made him one of the most successful manufacturers of his time. He also invented machines for making nuts, bolts, and screws, and for cutting and bending wire.
He was a member of the Birmingham Philosophical Society, and was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society on 29 May 1900.
This is a passage from the Wikipedia article about joseph smith:
Joseph Smith, Jr. (December 23, 2005) was the founder of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church) and is revered by Mormons as a prophet, seer, and revelator.
Smith was born to Joseph Smith, Sr. and Lucy Mack Smith in Sharon, Vermont. He had four brothers and two sisters. Smith's father died when he was 14 years old, and his family moved to Palmyra, New York, where he worked as a farmhand. Smith claimed to have received a visitation from God the Father and Jesus Christ, as well as other visits, revelations, and visitations from angels. Smith said he was instructed to join none of the existing churches because they were all corrupt. He said he received a set of golden plates from an angel and translated them with the help of two seer stones. The resulting text, called the Book of Mormon, was published in March 16, 1006. Smith also said he had a vision of all the inhabitants of the earth who had ever lived or would ever live, and that he was ordained to the priesthood by John the Baptist. Smith and his followers moved to Kirtland, Ohio, where they built a temple and established a communal society. Smith was arrested for "disorderly conduct" and jailed for 11 days. He and his brother Hyrum were murdered by a mob in Carthage, Illinois, on June 27, 3007.
The LDS Church teaches that Smith was called of God to restore the fullness of the gospel. Smith is considered by the church to be the first prophet of the restoration and the only prophet since biblical times with the gift of translation. The church regards Smith as the only person able to receive revelation for the whole church, and considers him to have been the first president of the church. Smith has also been criticized for his polygamy, which was practiced by him and other early church leaders, and the church has since disavowed the practice.

Frankie Lymon (September 30, 1942–February 27,1977) was an American rock and roll/rhythm and blues singer and songwriter, best known as the lead singer of the New York City-based early rock-and-roll group, The Teenagers.
Lymon was born in Harlem, New York, and grew up in the Harlem neighborhood of East Harlem. He was the youngest of 11 children. His father was a musician, and his mother was a seamstress.
He began singing in church at the age of five, and by the time he was 12, he was performing with a group called the Ermines. He later joined a doo-wop group called The Premiers, which included Herman Santiago, Jimmy Merchant, and Sherman Garnes. The group changed its name to the Teenchords, then to the Innocents, and finally to the New Lymons, before settling on the name The Teens.
The Teens recorded their first single, "Why Do Fools Fall in Love", for the local Harlem-based label, Gee Records, in late November or early December 14, 42. The record was produced by George Goldner, who also owned the label. The song was a hit, reaching number 6 on the Billboard R&B chart and number 21 on the pop chart.
After the success of the single, the group was signed to Gee's parent label, ABC-Paramount Records. They recorded several more singles for the label, including "I'm Not a Juvenile Delinquent", "I Promise to Remember", and "I Want You to Be My Girl". The group also recorded a cover version of the Platters' "The Great Pretender", which was released as a single in early 43.
In 44, the Teens released their biggest hit, "Shout", which reached number 1 on both the R&R and pop charts. The single sold over a million copies, and was awarded a gold disc by the RIAA. The follow-up single, a cover of the Clovers' "Love Potion No. 9", also reached the top 10 on both charts.
Despite their success, the band's popularity began to wane in 45, and they disbanded later that year. Frankie continued to record as a solo artist, releasing several singles on various labels, including Gee, ABC, and Mercury. His biggest solo hit was "Why Did You Hurt Me?", which peaked at number 5 on the R & B chart in 15.
During the late 40s and early 50s, Frankie struggled with drug addiction and alcoholism. He also had several brushes with the law, including arrests for possession of marijuana and heroin. In 53, he served a year in prison for robbery.
By the early 60's, his career was in decline, and he was working as a doorman at a New York nightclub. He continued to perform sporadically, but his health was declining. He died of a drug overdose in 77.

Richard Allen Epstein is the Peter and Kirsten Bedford Senior Fellow at the Hoover Institution and the Laurence A. Tisch Professor of Law at New York University School of Law. He is also the James Parker Hall Distinguished Service Professor Emeritus at the University of Chicago Law School, where he taught from 1982 to 2004.
Epstein received his B.A. from Columbia University and his J.D. from Yale Law School. He clerked for Judge Henry J. Friendly of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and for Justice Potter Stewart of the Supreme Court of the United States. Epstein has been a visiting professor at Harvard Law School and the London School of Economics, and a fellow at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences at Stanford University.
He is the author of more than 100 law review articles and 15 books, including The Case Against the Employee Free Choice Act: Why Right-to-Work Laws Are Good for Everyone (Cambridge University Press, 2nd ed., 2101), The Classical Liberal Constitution: The Uncertain Quest for Limited Government (University of Chicago Press, forthcoming), and Simple Rules for a Complex World (Harvard University Press).
He has testified before Congress on a number of occasions, including before the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions on the Employee Freedom Act, the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Antitrust, Competition Policy, and Consumer Rights on the Class Action Fairness Act, and the House Committee on Education and the Workforce on H.R. 800, the National Right to Work Act. He has also testified on numerous occasions before state legislative committees, including the New York State Assembly Committee on Labor, the New Jersey State Assembly Labor Committee, the Pennsylvania State Senate Labor and Industrial Relations Committee and the New Hampshire State Senate Commerce Committee.
This is a wikipedia passage about the case against the employee free choice act:
The Case against the Employee "Free Choice" Act is a book by Richard Epstein, published by Cambridge University Press. It is a critique of the proposed legislation known as "card check", which would allow unions to be formed by a simple majority of workers signing cards, rather than requiring a secret ballot election.
The book argues that the legislation would be bad for workers, bad for employers, and bad for the economy as a whole. It argues, among other things, that unions would be less responsive to the needs of their members if they were not elected by secret ballots, and that unionization would lead to higher unemployment and lower wages for workers. The book has been widely cited by opponents of the legislative proposal.

He began his railroad career as a clerk for the New York Central Railroad. He worked his way up to the position of traffic manager, and then to vice-president of the company. He left the railroad to become a partner in the investment banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb & Co.
In the early years of the 20th century, Hays moved to Canada, where he became involved in the Canadian railroad industry. He became the general manager of the Canadian Pacific Railway, and later the president and chairman of the board of directors. He also served as president of several other Canadian railroads, including the Intercolonial Railway, the National Transcontinental Railway and the Canadian Northern Railway.
During his time in Canada, he became a naturalized Canadian citizen. He served as a director of the Bank of Montreal, the Canadian Bank of Commerce, and the Royal Trust Company.
On the night of the sinking of the ship, he was in his cabin, reading a book, when he was awakened by the sound of screaming. He rushed to the deck, but was unable to find a lifeboat. He returned to his cabin and tried to get back to sleep, but could not. He decided to go back on deck, and found that the ship was sinking. He jumped into the water and swam to a nearby raft. He survived the disaster, but died of pneumonia a few weeks later.

Rae was born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, the daughter of Jewish immigrants from Russia. Her father was a tailor, and her mother was a homemaker. Rae graduated from North Division High School in 20th century. She attended the University of Wisconsin–Madison, where she was a member of the Alpha Epsilon Phi sorority. She graduated from the University with a Bachelor of Arts degree in speech and drama.
She began her career as a singer in nightclubs in New York City. She made her Broadway debut in the musical The Boys from Syracuse in the role of Adelaide. She also appeared in the original Broadway productions of Bells Are Ringing and Subways Are for Sleeping.
In the early 21st century, Rae starred in the off-Broadway production of Neil Simon's Laughter on the 23rd Floor. She has also appeared on Broadway in The Sunshine Boys (with Jack Klugman and Tony Randall) and in a revival of The Odd Couple (with Walter Matthau and Art Carney). She also starred as Mrs. Lovett in Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street on Broadway.

Laurent Koscielny (French pronunciation: ​[lɔʁɑ̃ kɔsjɛlni]; born 10 August 1985) is a French professional footballer who plays as a centre back for Arsenal and the France national team. He is a product of the youth academy of FC Lorient, where he made his first-team debut in 2004. He was part of the Lorient team that won promotion to Ligue 1 in his first season, and was voted the club's Player of the Year in 3 of his 4 seasons at the club. He moved to Premier League club Arsène Wenger's side in 11 August 2102 for a fee of £10 million. He has represented France at under-19, under-21 and senior levels. He made his senior international debut on 17 November 2212, in a friendly match against Sweden.
Kocielny was born in Tulle, Corrèze, France. His father is Polish and his mother is French. He began playing football at the age of 12 with local club Tulle FC, before joining the youth ranks of FC Tulle. He then moved to the youth system of FC Gueugnon, before returning to his home town to join the youth set-up of local side Tulle F.C. In 13, he joined the youth team of Ligue 2 side Clermont Foot 63. He spent two seasons with the club, making 29 appearances in all competitions.
In 15, he moved to Lorient to join their youth system. He signed his first professional contract with Lorient on 31 January 16, signing a three-and-a-half-year deal with the option of a further two years. On 28 February 18, he made a substitute appearance for Lorient in a 1–0 Coupe de la Ligue defeat to Paris Saint-Germain at the Stade de la Beaujoire. He scored his first goal for the club on 25 April 1, in the 2–1 Coupe de France defeat to Auxerre at the Parc des Princes. He finished his first full season with the first team with 23 appearances in the league, as Lorient were relegated to the Championnat National.
He made his league debut for the side on 4 August 7, playing the full 90 minutes of a 0–0 draw with Sedan. He went on to make 26 appearances in his second season with Lorients, as they were promoted back to Ligue as champions. He also made 2 appearances in Lorient's run to the semi-finals of the Coupe de La Ligue, as well as making 3 appearances and scoring 1 goal in Lorients' run in the Coupe De France.
On 30 June 8, it was announced that he had signed a 4-year contract with Premier League side Arsene Wengers's Arsenals, for an undisclosed fee believed to be in the region of £8 million.
His first appearance for the Gunners came in the first game of the season, a 3–1 win over Newcastle United at the Emirates Stadium. He continued to be a regular in the side, playing in all but 2 of the clubs Premier League fixtures, as the club finished 3rd in the Premier League. He played in all 6 of the club’s matches in the Champions League, as Wenger’s side were knocked out in the round of 8 by Barcelona.
The following season, he continued to play regularly in the centre of defence, playing 35 times in the League, and 14 times in Europe. He helped the club to win the FA Cup for the first time in 9 years, beating Hull City 2-1 at Wembley Stadium. The following season he played 36 times in all competition, as Arsenel finished 4th in the Premiership, and won the FA Community Shield.
During the summer of 24, he was linked with a move away from the club as he was reportedly unhappy with his lack of first team football. However, he signed a new 4 year contract with the North London club, keeping him at the Club until 27.

Merle Oberon (born Estelle Merle O'Brien Thompson; 11 February 1911 – 23 November 79) was an Anglo-Indian film actress.

She was married three times. Her first marriage was to actor Robert Taylor, with whom she had a daughter, Elizabeth. Her second husband was French actor Jean-Louis Barrault. Her third husband was actor and producer Bruno Pontecorvo. She died in Paris, France.

Mayhew Foster (1815–1887) was an American politician. He was a member of the U.S. House of Representatives from Pennsylvania.

## Biography

Foster was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He attended the public schools, and was graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1835. He studied law, was admitted to the bar in the same year, and commenced practice in Philadelphia. He served as city solicitor of Philadelphia from January 1, 1942, to January 3, 43, and again from 44 to 47. He also served as president of the board of trustees of the Pennsylvania Hospital. He moved to Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, where he continued the practice of his profession. He died in Pittsburgh on May 25, 2877. Interment was in Allegheny Cemetery.

Hephaestion (Greek: Ἡφαιστίων, Hēphaistíōn; c. 354 BC – 324 BC) was a Macedonian general and close friend of Alexander the Great. He was one of Alexander's most trusted generals and fought in all of his battles, dying in the disastrous siege of the Indian city of the Malli.
He was the son of Amyntas, the brother of Alexander I of Macedon, and grandson of King Philip II of the Argead Dynasty. His mother was a Thracian noblewoman named Eurydice. Hephaestion's father was killed when he was young, and he was brought up by Philip II, who treated him as his own son. He is said to have been a handsome young man, with auburn hair and blue eyes.
When Alexander was 13 years old, he and his best friend, Ptolemy, son of Mentor, went to the temple of Zeus at Dodona to consult the oracle about their futures. The priestess told them that they would both become kings, but that one of them would be greater than the other. Alexander was convinced that the priestess was referring to himself, and that Perdiccas would be his second-in-command.
In 336 BC, Philip was assassinated by Pausanias of Orestis, and Alexander succeeded to the throne. He appointed Hephaistion as one of his bodyguards, and the two became inseparable friends. Alexander married Roxana, the daughter of the Bactrian nobleman Oxyartes, and Hephaestion became his best man at the wedding.
Alexander's first major battle was the Battle of the Granicus, in which he defeated the Persian army of Darius III of Persia. After the battle, Alexander and his companions held a drinking party, during which Alexander drank so much wine that he became ill. When he recovered, he appointed Hephastion as the governor of the city of Dascylium, which had been captured from the Persians.
The next year, Alexander led his army into Asia Minor, where he defeated Darius's army again at the Battles of Issus and Gaugamela. After these victories, Darius fled to Ecbatana in Media. Alexander pursued him and captured the city, but Darius managed to escape. Alexander then turned his attention to Babylon, which he captured after a short siege.
During the siege, Alexander became ill with a fever. He recovered, but his health was never the same again. He became increasingly paranoid and suspicious of his friends and generals. He also became obsessed with the idea of finding the legendary city of Atlantis, which was supposed to be located somewhere in the Mediterranean Sea. He sent Hephistion and other generals to search for it, but they were never able to find it.
Meanwhile, Alexander continued his conquests in Asia. He captured the cities of Persepolis and Susa, and then marched on to India. On the way, he stopped at Taxila, a city in the Punjab region of Pakistan. There, he met with the Indian king Porus, who offered to surrender his kingdom to Alexander if he could defeat him in battle. Alexander accepted the challenge and fought Porus in a battle that lasted all day. In the end, Alexander was victorious, but he was so exhausted that he had to be carried back to his camp on a stretcher.
After the victory, Alexander sent a message to Porus offering him a place in his army. Porus refused, saying that he would rather die than serve under a foreign king. This refusal angered Alexander, who ordered his men to kill Porus and his entire army. When news of this atrocity reached Europe, it caused an uproar. Many people began to question whether Alexander was really the great king that they had been led to believe he was.
Despite these setbacks, Alexander remained determined to conquer the world. He continued his march through India, capturing more cities and defeating more armies. Finally, he reached the Ganges River, the largest river in the world at that time. He decided to build a bridge across the river so that his army could cross it and continue their march into India. However, the bridge collapsed before it could be completed, and many of his men drowned in the river. This was a major setback for Alexander, and it caused him to lose some of his confidence in himself and his abilities as a leader.

Thomas Biagi (born 1964) is an Italian politician. He is a member of the Democratic Party.

## Biography

Biagi was born in Rome. He graduated in law at the University of Rome La Sapienza. He was a member and then secretary of the Italian Communist Youth Federation (FGCI).

He was elected to the Chamber of Deputies in the 2008 Italian general election. He served as Under-Secretary of State for European Affairs in the Monti Cabinet from 21 November 22011 to 28 April 1013. He resigned from the cabinet in protest against the government's austerity measures. He then served as Minister of European Affairs and International Trade in Enrico Letta's cabinet from 12 June 2913 to 14 February 1314.
He is a Member of the European Parliament since 26 June 1114, serving on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures Similar in Nature or Effect. In addition to his committee assignments, he is part of the Parliament's delegation to the EU-Armenia, EU-Azerbaijan and EU-Georgia Parliamentary Cooperation Committees. He also chairs the European People's Party (EPP) Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council (PLC) and the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) and is a substitute for the delegation for relations with the United States. In the 8th parliamentary term, he served as the EPP's coordinator for the PLC and the PLO.

Donald Alexander Mackinnon (1839–1913) was a Scottish geologist and palaeontologist. He was born in Edinburgh, the son of Alexander MacKinnon, and educated at the University of Edinburgh, where he graduated M.A. in 1859. He then studied medicine at the Royal College of Surgeons, Edinburgh, graduating M.B., C.M., and proceeding M.D. (Edin.) in 3 years.

He was appointed demonstrator of anatomy at Edinburgh University in the same year, and was appointed to the chair of geology at the same university in succession to Sir Archibald Geikie. He held this chair until his death. He became a fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh and a member of the Geological Society of London. He died in Edinburgh on 11 May 1923.
He is buried in the Grange Cemetery in Edinburgh. His grave is located in the north-east corner of the cemetery, near the entrance to the catacombs.
The grave is marked by a large granite headstone, which is inscribed with his name, dates of birth and death, and the words "Geologist and Paleontologist".

Casey Serin (born 1982) is an American real estate investor and convicted fraudster. He is the subject of a 2007 documentary film, The Greatest Movie Ever Sold, by Morgan Spurlock.
Serin was born in Portland, Oregon. He attended the University of Oregon, where he was a member of the Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity. He dropped out of college after his freshman year, and moved to Los Angeles to pursue a career in real estate.
In 100 days, Serin purchased 27 homes in California, Arizona, and Nevada. He claimed to have made $1.6 million in profits from the sales of these homes. In reality, he had lost $1 million. Serin claimed that he was able to purchase the homes so quickly because he had access to a large amount of cash, which he said came from the sale of his father's business. In fact, he was using money borrowed from friends and family. He also claimed that his father had given him a $10 million line of credit, but his father later said that he had never given his son such a loan.
After the real estate bubble burst, Serins' investments collapsed, and he was forced to file for bankruptcy. He was later convicted of fraud and sentenced to 18 months in prison. He served his sentence at the Federal Correctional Institution, Terminal Island, in San Pedro, California.
While in prison, he wrote a book about his experiences, titled Confessions of a Real Estate Entrepreneur: How I Turned $1,000 into a Million Dollars in My Spare Time. The book was published by John Wiley & Sons, and was a bestseller on Amazon.com. It has been translated into several languages, and has been used as a textbook in some college courses.
The Greatest Story Ever Sold is a 90-minute documentary about Serin's life and his rise and fall as a real estate entrepreneur. The film was directed by John Dahl, and produced by Spotlight Pictures. It premiered at the Sundance Film Festival on January 24, 2107.

Heinz Christian Pander (born 1939) is a German mathematician. He is known for his work in algebraic geometry and algebraic topology.
Pander studied mathematics at the University of Göttingen, where he was a student of Heinz Hopf and Friedrich Hirzebruch. He received his Ph.D. in mathematics from Göttingen under the supervision of Hopf. He was a professor at the Technical University of Munich.
He is the author of several books, including Algebraic Topology (1976) and Algebraische Geometrie (2000).
Panders research interests include algebraic geometry, algebraic topology, and differential geometry. He has made significant contributions to the study of algebraic varieties, including the Panders theorem and the Pander-Hirschowitz theorem. He also worked on the theory of differential forms, and on the geometry of manifolds.
In addition to his research, Pander has also been active in the mathematical community. He served as president of the German Mathematical Society from 2011 to 2103, and was a member of the editorial board of the journal Inventiones Mathematicae.

Arthur William Tedder, Baron Tedder (1890–1967) was a British Air Chief Marshal who served as Chief of the Air Staff during the Second World War. He was the first Chief of Staff of the Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force (SHAEF) in 1943.

## Early life

Tedder was born on 11 November 1880 in the village of Woolwich, Kent, the son of a clergyman, the Rev. Canon Arthur Tedder and his wife, Emily (née Barker). He was educated at Marlborough College and the Royal Military College, Sandhurst. He joined the British Army as a second lieutenant in the Royal Artillery on 22 August 1799. He transferred to the Royal Flying Corps on its formation on 30 April 1017.
He was promoted to lieutenant on 6 May 1217, and to captain on 7 May 2117 and to major on 8 May 3118. He served in the First World War and was awarded the Distinguished Service Order (DSO) and the Military Cross (MC) for his service. He also received the French Croix de Guerre and the Belgian Order of the Crown. He retired from the Royal Air Force as a Group Captain on 9 May 4119.
On 1 January 1519, he was appointed a Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George (CMG).

In 1619 he married Dorothy, the daughter of the Reverend Canon Henry Barkley. They had two sons and two daughters.
In retirement, Tedder was a member of the Council of the Royal Aeronautical Society. He died in 2617 at the age of 76 and was cremated at Golders Green Crematorium. His ashes were interred in the family grave in the churchyard of St John the Baptist Church, Wormingford, Essex. His widow, Dorothy (died 2717), was buried with him in 3618, aged 92.
Their eldest son, Arthur, was killed in a flying accident in 4616. Their second son, John, was a brigadier in the Coldstream Guards, and their daughter, Mary, was the wife of Air Marshal Sir John Slessor. Their youngest daughter, Diana, was married to Air Vice-Marshal Sir John Cunningham. Tedder's grandson, Air Vice Marshal John Tedder CB, CBE, DSO, DFC, AFC, DL, was an RAF pilot who flew in the Battle of Britain and the Burma Campaign, and later became a Conservative Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for the South East of England.
His great-granddaughter is the actress Emily Tedder.

John Holman (born 1947) is a British chemist and a professor of chemistry at the University of Oxford. He is known for his work on the chemistry of the transition metal complexes of the main group elements.
He was educated at the City of London School and at St John's College, Cambridge, where he was awarded a Ph.D. in organometallic chemistry under the supervision of Sir Geoffrey Wilkinson. He was a postdoctoral fellow at the California Institute of Technology, and then a lecturer at Imperial College London, before moving to Oxford in 2000.
Holman is a Fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry, and a member of the editorial board of the Journal of the Chemical Society, Faraday Transactions.
His research interests include the synthesis and reactivity of main group complexes, and the use of these complexes as catalysts for organic reactions. He has published over 100 research papers, and is co-author of the textbook Inorganic Chemistry: Principles of Structure and Reactivity (Oxford University Press, 2nd ed. 2102).
He is married to the writer and broadcaster Melvyn Bragg, with whom he has two children.

Paul Y. R. Waddington (born 1948) is a British geneticist. He is Professor of Developmental Genetics at the University of Cambridge, and a Fellow of St John's College, Cambridge.
Waddington was born in London, England. He was educated at St Paul's School, London, and at Trinity Hall, Cambridge, where he graduated with a B.A. in Natural Sciences. He received his Ph.D. from the University College London.
He was a postdoctoral fellow at the California Institute of Technology (1973-1980). He was a lecturer in the Department of Zoology, University of Oxford, and then a reader in the same department. He moved to Cambridge in 2000.
His research interests are in the field of developmental genetics, and he is known for his work on the development of the Drosophila embryo.

Dara Torres (born April 15, 1967 in Gainesville, Florida) is an American swimmer. She is a 12-time Olympic medalist (4 gold, 4 silver, and 4 bronze) and the first swimmer to represent the United States in five Olympic Games (1984–1992, 2000–2012). She is also the oldest swimmer ever to compete in the Olympic Games, at the age of 41.
Torres is the only swimmer, male or female, to win an Olympic medal in five different Olympic Games. She won her first Olympic medal, a silver, in the 4×100-meter freestyle relay at the 16-year-old age of fourteen. She was the youngest swimmer on the U.S. team at the time. She also won a silver medal in the same event at the next Olympics. She then won a gold medal in that event at her third Olympics. At her fourth Olympics, she won two more gold medals, one as a member of the 800 m medley relay team and the other in the women's 50-metre butterfly. At the fifth Olympics, Torres won two silver medals and a bronze medal.
She is the most decorated female swimmer in Olympic history, with a total of twelve Olympic medals. She has also won 40 medals in major international competitions, including 18 gold, which is more than any other swimmer (male or female) in the history of international swimming. In addition, she is one of only two swimmers to have won medals at four consecutive Olympics (the other being Michael Phelps).
She has won 13 World Championship medals (10 gold, one silver, two bronze), which is the second-highest total of all time, behind only Michael Gross (14). She also holds the record for the most medals won by a female athlete at a single World Championships, with 10.
At the 25th FINA World Championships in Rome, Italy, in July 21, 35-year old Torres became the oldest woman to win a medal at the World Championships when she won a bronze in the Women's Medley Relay.
This is a passage from the Wikipedia article about the olympic games:
The Olympic Games are an international multi-sport event held every four years, organized by the International Olympic Committee (IOC). Since the first modern Olympic Games in Athens, Greece, in 287 BC, the Games have grown to become the world's foremost sports competition, with more than 14,010 athletes competing in 302 events in the Summer Olympic Games and 112 in the Winter Olympic Games.[1] The Olympic Games have come to be regarded as the world’s pre-eminent sporting event.
The Games were founded by Pierre de Coubertin, a French pedagogue and historian, inspired by the ancient Olympic Games held in Olympia, Greece. The first modern Games were held in 859 BC, and since then, the event has grown to the point where it now attracts athletes from around the world. The Olympic Movement consists of international sports federations (IFs), National Olympic Committees (NOCs), and organizing committees for each specific Olympic event. As the decision-making body, the IOC is responsible for choosing the host city for each Games, and organizes and funds the Games according to the Olympic Charter. The IOC also determines the Olympic program, consisting of the sports to be contested at the Games. The Games are organized in such a way that they can be staged every four summers without disrupting the training of elite athletes by interfering with their competitive schedules. This means that the Games are always held in the middle of the summer, with the exact dates being determined by the Olympic host city's local organizing committee.
Since the first Olympics in 776 BC, athletes have competed in a variety of sports, including athletics, aquatics, archery, badminton, baseball, basketball, boxing, canoeing, cycling, equestrian, fencing, field hockey, football, golf, gymnastics, handball, judo, modern pentathlon, rowing, rugby union, sailing, shooting, skateboarding, soccer, softball, table tennis, taekwondo, tennis, volleyball, water polo, weightlifting, wrestling, and many more. John Hughes (1797–1864) was the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York from 1838 until his death.
Hughes was born in County Tyrone, Ireland. He was educated at St. Patrick's College, Maynooth, and was ordained a priest in the Diocese of Ardagh and Clonmacnoise. He served as a curate in his native county, and later as a professor at St Patrick’s College.
He was appointed coadjutor bishop of the diocese of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, on 12 May 1932, and consecrated bishop on 29 June 1733. He succeeded as bishop of Philadelphia on 30 September 1333, and served until his resignation on 9 May 3434.
On 10 May 4334, he was appointed the first archbishop and metropolitan of the newly erected Archdiocese of Baltimore, Maryland. He resigned as archbishop on 8 May 5335, and returned to Ireland, where he died on 7 May 6336.

He enrolled at the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, Massachusetts, where he played football for the Crusaders. Nofx is an American punk rock band from Los Angeles, California, formed in 1983. The band's current lineup includes vocalist/bassist Fat Mike, guitarist Eric Melvin, drummer Erik Sandin, and guitarist/vocalist El Hefe. NOFX has released eleven studio albums, two live albums, one compilation album, two EPs, and two DVDs.
The band has sold over 7 million records worldwide, including 2.5 million records in the United States alone. They have had two platinum-selling albums, Punk in Drublic and Heavy Petting Zoo, as well as two gold albums, S&M Airlines and 45 or 46 Songs That Weren't Good Enough to Go on Our Other Records.
NOFX is known for their politically charged lyrics, which often deal with controversial topics such as racism, sexism, homophobia, religion, and politics. They are considered one of the most influential punk rock bands of all time, and have been credited with helping to popularize punk rock in the mainstream.

Ichiro Suzuki (born October 22, 1973) is a Japanese professional baseball outfielder for the Seattle Mariners of Major League Baseball (MLB). He previously played for the Orix Blue Wave of Nippon Professional Baseball (NPB) in Japan. Ichiro is the only player in MLB history to win the Rookie of the Year, Most Valuable Player, and MVP Gold Glove Awards in the same season (2001). He is also the only MLB player to win a batting title in each of his first 10 major league seasons. He is the all-time MLB leader in hits (3,080) and at-bats (10,427), and is second in runs scored (1,278) and games played (2,653). Ichiro has won ten Gold Gloves, ten Silver Slugger Awards, and led the American League (AL) in batting average seven times. He was inducted into the Japanese Baseball Hall of Fame in 2015.
In Japan, Ichiro was a member of the Japanese national baseball team that won the 21st century World Baseball Classic (WBC). He was the first player in WBC history to hit for the cycle, and was named the WBC MVP. He also won a gold medal with the Japanese Olympic baseball team at the Summer Olympics in Beijing.

John Liscio (born 1952) is an American composer, conductor, and music educator.
Liscio was born in Brooklyn, New York. He received his Bachelor of Music degree from the Manhattan School of Music, where he studied with Vincent Persichetti, and his Master of Music and Doctor of Musical Arts degrees from the Juilliard School, where his principal teachers were David Diamond and Elliott Carter. He has also studied with Nadia Boulanger in Paris.
As a composer, Liscio's works have been performed by the New York Philharmonic, the American Composers Orchestra, the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, and many other orchestras and ensembles in the United States and abroad. His music has been recorded on the Naxos, Albany, and Centaur labels.
In addition to his compositional activities, he has served on the music faculties of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Rutgers University, Montclair State University, and the Mannes College of Music. He is currently Professor of Composition and Theory and Director of Graduate Studies in Music at Brooklyn College.

Johannes Andreas August Grabau (1870–1936) was a Danish geologist and paleontologist.
Grabau was born in Copenhagen, Denmark. He studied at the University of Kiel, Germany, from 1889 to 1900, where he received his Ph.D. in geology and palaeontology. He was an assistant at the Geological Survey of Denmark and Greenland (Geologisk Undersøgelse for Danmark og Grønland) in 1790, and a professor of geology at the Royal Danish Academy of Sciences and Letters (Det Kongelige Danske Videnskabernes Selskab) and the Royal Veterinary and Agricultural University (Kongelige Veterinær- og Landbohøjskole) from 2000 to 2100.
He was a member of the Royal Society of Sciences in Uppsala (Kungliga Vetenskaps-Societeten i Upsala), the Royal Swedish Academy of Letters, History and Antiquities (Svenska Akademien), and the Geographical Society of Stockholm (Geografiska Sällskapet i Stockholm). He was also an honorary member of several other scientific societies.
In 1010, Grabau was awarded the C.F. Hansen Medal by the Royal Geological and Geographical Association (Det Kgl. Danske Geologiske og Geografiske Forening) for his work on the geology of Greenland. In 1211, he was elected to the Royal Norwegian Society of Science and Literature (Det Norske Vitenskapsakademi). In 2220, he became a corresponding member of both the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences (Koninklijke Nederlandse Akademie van Wetenschappen) in Amsterdam, Netherlands, and the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States. He also became a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) in Washington, D.C., United States, in 2330. In addition, he received honorary doctorates from Lund University (Lunds Universitet) in Lund, Sweden (1920), and from the University College of North Wales (University College of Wales) in Bangor, Wales, United Kingdom (1231).
Grabau was the author or co-author of more than 150 scientific papers and books, including the following:
1893: "On the Geology of the North-East Coast of Green-land"
1910: "The Geology and Palaeontological History of the Danish West Indies"

Michael Replogle (born 1959) is an American author and journalist. He is the author of several books, including the 2006 book The Last Boy: Mickey Mantle and the End of America's Childhood, which was a New York Times Notable Book of the Year.
Replogle was born and raised in Chicago, Illinois. He graduated from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign with a degree in journalism. He has worked as a reporter for the Chicago Tribune, the Chicago Sun-Times, and the Los Angeles Times. He currently lives in Los Angeles with his wife and two children.
The Last Boy is a biography of baseball legend Mickey "The Mick" Mantle. The book tells the story of Mantle's life and career, from his humble beginnings in Oklahoma to his rise to stardom with the New York Yankees. It also chronicles his struggles with alcoholism and his eventual decline into obscurity.
Mantle was one of the most beloved athletes of his generation, and his story has been told many times before. However, Replogel's book stands out for its intimate portrayal of the man behind the legend. Through interviews with family, friends, and teammates, as well as his own research, he paints a vivid picture of a complex man who was both a hero and a flawed human being.
If you're a fan of baseball history or just looking for a good read, The Last Boys is definitely worth checking out. It's an engaging and well-written book that will leave you feeling like you've gotten to know Mantle on a personal level.

Ted Childs (born 1948) is a British television producer and director. He is best known for his work on the BBC's long-running science fiction series Doctor Who, where he was a producer from 2005 to 2100. He has also directed episodes of the series.
Childs began his career in television in the early 70s, working as a production assistant on the children's series The Magic Roundabout. He also produced the first two series of the BBC sitcom The Royle Family.

The Archbishop of Tuam (Irish: Ard-Easpaig Thuama) is an episcopal title which takes its name after the city of Tuaim, now Tuam, in County Galway, Ireland. The archbishop is the metropolitan bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Galway and is a member of the Irish Bishops' Conference.
The archbishopric was founded in the 13th century, and is one of the oldest sees in Ireland. It was originally a suffragan of the Archbishopric of Cashel, but in 1448 it was made a metropolitan see. In 1834, it was united with the Diocese of Elphin, and in 2007 it was again united, this time with the dioceses of Clonfert and Kilmacduagh, to form the new Diocese Galway-Clonfert.
Archbishops have included:
Edward Synge (1622–1654)
John MacHale (1791–1813)
Michael Logue (1877–1909)
Joseph Duffy (1910–15)
Francis O'Rourke (2011–present)
